sender.senderstreetaddress: Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corp. Bldg 419, One Health Plaza

reaction.primarysourcereaction: Fell in her home/ Patient fell again

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
This is an initial PMS study report received from nurse on 09 Jan 2009. The patient received Sandostatin LAR (octreotide acetate) 20 mg once a month for acromegaly since 12 Dec 2008. The patient was hospitalized for one week in Dec for bowel surgery as patient had a kinked bowel. Outcome and causality assessment were not provided by reporting nurse. In the absence of a health care professional's causality, the Novartis Medical Safety Physician has provisionally assessed a relationship between the event gastrointestinal disorder and Sandostatin as not suspected based on the current available information.
Follow-up report received from the home health nurse via email on 25 Aug 2009. Case changed from PMS to SR as per new procedures. The patient's daughter contacted nurse to cancel the visit as the patient was in hospital for intestinal problems.
Follow-up information from a consumer received on 18 Sep 2009: On 21 Aug 2009, patient was admitted to hospital and had surgery approximately 5 weeks back to shorten her intestines which were too long. On 12 Sep 2009, she was discharged and was recovering well.
Follow-up report received from the home health nurse on 10 Aug 2009. This patient was hospitalized for a bowel obstruction where he underwent surgery for kinked bowel.
Follow up received from nurse on 10 Dec 2009: The patient was on Sandostatin LAR 30 mg/ monthly. She was hospitalized for bowel obstruction for 2 weeks. Her BP was 144/60. The outcome was not reported.
Follow up received from nurse on 10 Mar 2010: On an unknown date, the patient's BP was 160/80. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow up report received from nurse on 11 May 2010: This patient's Sandostatin LAR dose was increased to 30 mg once a month for acromegaly since an unspecified date. On an unknown date, her BP was reported as 150/80. The outcome was not reported.
Follow-up received from consumer on 07 Jul 2010: This patient would undergo a surgery for glaucoma on 13 Jul 2010. It was reported that, it was unclear when glaucoma was started but the reporter thought that glaucoma was recently developed. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow up information received from the physician on 05 Aug 2010: It was reported patient did not experienced an adverse affect relating to Sandostatin LAR. When the patient went for cataract surgery, her daughter misunderstood that she had glaucoma and that that may be secondary to her injections however this was wrong information. It was reported that there was no contraindications for the client to resume her injections.
Follow up received from nurse on 14 Oct 2010: On an unknown date, the patient's BP was 158/80. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow-up nurse report received via Access Program on 13 Dec 2010: This patient's Sandostatin LAR dose was increased to 40 mg once a month (date unknown). On an unspecified date, the patient's blood pressure was 164/82. The outcome was not reported.
Follow-up information was received from a nurse via Access program on 09 Feb 2011: On an unspecified date the patient's blood pressure was 150/80. The outcome of the events was not reported. No other information was available.
Follow-up nurse report received via Access Program on 09 Mar 2011: On an unspecified date, the patient's blood pressure was 164/82. The outcome was not reported.
Follow-up report received from a nurse via Access Program on 08 Apr 2011: This patient's blood pressure was at 150/80 on an unknown date. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow-up nurse report received on 05 May 2011: On an unspecified date, the patient's blood pressure was 160/70. The outcome was not reported.
Follow-up report received from nurse on 09 Jun 2011 through Access Sandostatin program: On an unspecified date the patient complained of increased fatigue. Her blood pressure was recorded as 164/84. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow up report received from nurse on 11 Jul 2011: This patient received Sandostatin LAR 30 mg every 4 weeks. The patient's blood pressure was 142/98, on an unspecified date. The event outcome was not reported.
Follow up report received from nurse on 10 Aug 2011: On an unknown date, the patient's blood pressure was 170/94. The event outcome was not reported.
Follow up report received from HCP on 29 Aug 2011: HCP reported patient was seen on the 26 Aug 2011 and that no complaints associated with Sandostatin LAR were formulated. There was no adverse reaction to be reported.
Follow up received from nurse on 07 Sep 2011: On an unspecified date patient's blood pressure was 144/90. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow up received from nurse on 05 Oct 2011: It was reported that the treatment with Sandostatin LAR was discontinued on 11 Mar 2009. On 03 Oct 2011, the patient fell in her house. The patient then went to emergency room and stayed overnight. On an unspecified date, the patient was diagnosed with pneumonia and received treatment with antibiotics at home. The event outcome seriousness and causality were not reported.
Follow up report received from physician on 13 Oct 2011: Reporter stated that the patient experienced pneumonia and stayed overnight at the hospital. The physician stated that the event was not related to Sandostatin LAR and the outcome of the event was improving.
Follow up report received from a nurse via Access Sandostatin Program on 18 Apr 2012: On an unspecified date patient's blood pressure was 142/78. On an unspecified date Sandostatin LAR dose was increased to 40 mg once a month, intramuscularly. The event outcome seriousness and causality were not reported.
Follow-up information received from nurse via Access Sandostatin Program on 16 May 2012: On an unspecified date, the patient's blood pressure was 150/70. The event outcome, seriousness and causality were not reported.
Follow up report from nurse via Access Program received on 12 Jun 2012: The patient was at hospital since 06 Jun 2012 because the patient fell and they were doing a "blood work".
Follow up report received from nurse on 18 Jun 2012 via Access Marketing Program: On an unspecified date, the patient's blood pressure was 144/58 (Units and refrence values not provided). The patient was discharged from hospital on 15 Jun 2012. The outcome and causality were not reported.
Follow up report received from a consumer 26 Jun 2012: On an unspecified date in 2012, the patient had memory loss. It was attributed to antiparkin medication. This had already be discontinued. Seriousness were not reported. Causality was reported as not suspected to Sandostatin LAR therapy. The event outcome was reported as complete recovery.
Follow up report received from a nurse via marketing program (ACCESS Sandostatin) on 13 Aug 2012: On an unspecified date, the patient's blood pressure was found to be 164/80 (Units and refrence values not provided). The event outcome, seriousness and causality were not reported.
Follow up report received from a nurse via marketing program (ACCESS Sandostatin) on 10 Sep 2012: On an unknown date, the patient's blood pressure was 160/88 (Units and refrence values not provided). The outcome and causality of the event were not reported.
Follow up report received from a nurse via ACCESS Sandostatin on 06 Nov 2012: On an unknown date, the patient's blood pressure was 140/74 (Units and reference values not provided). The outcome and causality of the event were not reported.
Follow up report received from a nurse via ACCESS Sandostatin on 04 Dec 2012: It was reported that patient was hospitalized for vomiting roughly 2 weeks ago. Patient is coughing a lot with 'whitish sputum'. On an unknown date, the patient's blood pressure was 142/70. Seriousness, outcome and causality were not provided.
summary.sendercomment: MR: Event blood pressure increased and blood pressure diastolic decreased is better explained by the indication disease of acromegaly than by the product. However there is limited information to assess the other reported events.
